Who Said That First?: The Curious Origins of Common Words and Phrases


Exisle Publishing
Max Cryer
English 
2011 
ISBN: 1877437816, 0908988915 
319 pages 
PDF 
8.98 MB


Believe it or not, this is probably the first book to attempt to identify the original sources of some of the English language's most common expressions. We might think we know who first said 'famous for fifteen minutes', 'annus horribilis', 'the cold war' and 'let them eat cake'. It's 'a no brainer', you might say, but Max Cryer has a surprise or two in store for you. 'I kid you not'. In this very readable book, he explores the origins of hundreds of expressions we use and hear every day ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ and comes up with some surprising findings. Never 'economical with the truth', he might just have 'the last laugh'.

We learn that the Bible doesnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t mention Salome ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ or seven veilsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¦.
We learn about the origins of the infamous Mile High Club.
Written in Max CryerÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s delightfully witty style, WHO SAID THAT FIRST? is a wonderful book to dip into or settle a friendly dispute. Remember, good books are 'few and far between', and 'you get what you pay for'. So buy this book, 'go ahead, make my day'.

The inspiration for WHO SAID THAT FIRST?

One day when they were having lunch together, Max complimented her on the amount of pleasure she gave, and Lucille replied: ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‹Å“I would be absolutely nothing without the writers. ItÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s all to do with the way things are written ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ they create the springboard for me.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢

The remark stayed with Max for years, and he realised it was true. Very often the person who said an effective or memorable line didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t actually create it. As Lucille Ball had said, the person in the background should have the credit ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ but was usually invisible.
This is was what motivated him to seek not just popular expressions ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ but who had actually originated them.
